newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian soymeal prices ease on dull export demand.
newsitem.headline: Indian soymeal prices ease on dull export demand.

text.p: Indian soymeal export prices fell nearly four dollars per tonne during the past week on limited export demand, traders said on Tuesday.
They said Indian soymeal was currently quoted at $275-276 rupees per tonne fas against $278-280 rupees last week. It was quoted at around $216-218 rupees per tonne during the same period last year.
Traders expect a soybean crop of 3.5 million tonnes, of which 500,000 tonnes will be set aside for sowing in the next season.
About 2.4 million tonnes of soymeal will be produced from the remainder of the crop.
Of this 400,000 tonnes would be consumed domestically.
The remaining two million tonnes would be available for export in the new season, traders said.
Traders said Indian soymeal exporters had so far signed contracts to export around 1.3 million tonnes in 1996/97 (November-October) season compared to 1.5 million last year.
"We have 700,000 tonnes more (soymeal) available for export," said one trader.
India exported nearly 2.2 million tonnes of soymeal in 1995/96.

Indian soybean is currently quoted at 10,400-10,700 rupees per tonne compared to 8,300-8,600 rupees at the same time last year. In plant delivery condition, it was quoted at around 10,500-10,850 compared with 8,700-8,800 per tonne in the same period last year.
Soybean arrivals are around 15,000 tonnes each day compared with 20,000 tonnes last year in the markets of central India, the hub of India's soybean industry.
